Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly an amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of horse and rider to left (of rider, greaved left leg and foot remaining together with shield with dotted snake device and part of spear; of horse, part of rump and part of underbelly remaining).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The horse's body seems very long and the rider's leg appears quite short.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 38, pl. XVIII, no. 49)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 116-7, no. A196)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.159) (phase 3)
